headline: Opinion: The NDP’s shocking failures were laid bare in its B.C. strongholds - The Globe and Mail
context: A pedestrian makes their way past the office of NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh in Burnaby, B.C., during Election Day on April 28.Tijana Martin/The Globe and Mail

annotations.paragraph: You know the feeling when someone says something and you’re about to burst out laughing at their joke, and then you look at their face and stop yourself mid-LOL because you realize they’re actually being serious?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a personal anecdote and does not contribute directly to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: That was me at my door, when local Liberal candidate Mark Wiens came knocking a few weeks ago and shared with me that the Liberals had a real shot at winning Vancouver East.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a surprising political development relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: I live in one of those ridings that would vote New Democrat if the party ran a coyote as a candidate in a neighbourhood full of cats. It has been held by the NDP for a lifetime; it’s basically gone orange, with just two short interruptions by single-term Liberals, since 1961, most recently by Jenny Kwan and, before her, Libby Davies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the NDP's stronghold, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: And yet, Mr. Wiens wasn’t so far off – literally. He didn’t win, but received more than 20,000 votes to Ms. Kwan’s nearly 25,000 – which sounds like a comfortable victory, sure. But in this NDP stronghold? It was also a heck of a lot closer than four years ago, when Ms. Kwan won the riding by more than 18,000 votes over the Liberals.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific election results that highlight the NDP's weakening hold, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: A much bigger East Van shocker – and much slimmer margin – happened in the next riding over, Vancouver Kingsway. NDP stalwart Don Davies, who has represented the riding since 2008, won the 2021 election handily, with nearly double the number of votes as the Liberal, and the Conservative in a distant third.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides additional election results that illustrate the NDP's challenges, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: This week? Whoa. Mr. Davies was in the fight for his political life, and was finally declared the winner with the counting of the final poll Tuesday afternoon. He ultimately squeaked by the Liberal candidate by just over 300 votes. Four years earlier, he had won by nearly 10,000.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the election results for Mr. Davies, highlighting the NDP's struggles.

annotations.paragraph: What was even more astonishing was to see the growth of the Conservative vote in these very lefty ridings, where the roads are practically paved with granola and hemp seed.
annotations.reason: This paragraph comments on the surprising growth of the Conservative vote in traditionally NDP strongholds, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Of course, this is nothing compared to the outcome in Burnaby Central, where NDP leader Jagmeet Singh not only lost his seat, but came in a crushing third behind the Liberals and Conservatives.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a significant detail about Jagmeet Singh's loss, which is central to the article's focus on NDP failures.

annotations.paragraph: Going way east to Ottawa, the pshaw-ing could be heard all the way from here ahead of the election when The Globe and Mail reported that Mr. Poilievre was in trouble in his own Carleton riding.
annotations.reason: This paragraph shifts focus to Ottawa and Mr. Poilievre, which is unrelated to the NDP's performance in B.C.
This paragraph is vague and does not provide any new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: There are all kinds of factors that contribute to election shockers such as these. In the case of the New Democrats’ near-obliteration, the obvious conclusion is that there was a strong movement away from the NDP toward the other two main parties (I guess the only two main parties at the moment) because voters had strong opinions about who they wanted to lead the country through the Trumpocalypse: either the brainy economist, who many saw as the grown-up in the room; or the well-seasoned, scrappy politician, who can brawl with the best of them, and represented true change.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides analysis on the shift in voter preference away from the NDP, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: On change, I would argue that the Liberals ironically felt like the bigger change to many, with Justin Trudeau gone and political neophyte Mr. Carney stepping in. Mr. Poilievre could tack “for a change” onto as many sentences as he liked, but Canadians have been hearing him gripe for years now. Mr. Carney was a fresh face. And while change seemed desirable, in the midst of so much uncertainty, voters may have felt more comfortable with a safer kind of shift. And they wondered: Can the slogan guy take on the bully down south in a way this Oxford-educated numbers-guy can?
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the perception of change in political leadership, which indirectly relates to the NDP's failures.

annotations.paragraph: In any case, both the Liberals and Conservatives did well, even if the Conservatives did not win the election and the Liberals received only a minority. Such an outcome predicted even four months ago would have seen a political soothsayer laughed out of the room.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on the election outcome, which is relevant to understanding the NDP's performance.

annotations.paragraph: As we all know, a cascade of events allowed for such change – and saw the NDP lose most of its seats, and official party status.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly addresses the NDP's loss of seats and status, which is central to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Mr. Singh deserves recognition for what he has done for Canadians and praise for his style of leadership. His genuine warmth and humanity were evident in his emotional, eloquent speech for the ages Monday night.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is more about praising Mr. Singh's character rather than analyzing the NDP's failures.

annotations.paragraph: But beyond Mr. Singh personally, some soul-searching is in order. It’s easy to blame away a disappointing result. But is there another explanation in a riding where a seemingly safe seat went – or almost went – to a different candidate? Could it be something about Mr. Poilievre’s slogan-y antics? The NDP’s priorities? Its co-operation with the Trudeau Liberals?
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses potential reasons for the NDP's failures, which is directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: These results should at least prompt some hard looks in the mirror and, to use the word Mr. Carney employed in his victory speech, some humility.
annotations.reason: The paragraph suggests introspection for the NDP, which is relevant to the topic of their failures.
